topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Christian Idiodi, his role at SVPG, and previews major themes: why PMs are disliked, coaching, trust-building, and discovery methods, plus Christian’s work in Africa.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Jira Product Discovery (Atlassian) and Vanta, followed by Lenny welcoming Christian to the show.

topics.title: Why product managers are often disliked
topics.summary: Christian argues PMs are disliked largely because teams haven’t experienced competent PMs; trust comes from deep customer, business, and data competence, and poor competency leads to executive/sales-driven alternatives.

topics.title: How PMs earn trust and credibility
topics.summary: Christian recommends humility, deliberate learning, and borrowing trust by apprenticing with influential leaders—either asking them to teach you or offering to help—while continuously doing discovery so others see your growing competence.

topics.title: SVPG PM fundamentals: four product risks
topics.summary: Christian outlines the four key risks product teams must address—value, usability, feasibility, viability—and frames PM work as solving customer problems in ways customers reward and the business can sustain.

topics.title: Why value risk is most often missed
topics.summary: Christian explains that value is the hardest and most overlooked risk because roadmap/project-driven operating models assume value; he warns that usability tests and stated preferences don’t prove customers will buy/choose/use.

topics.title: Reference customers as the best discovery method
topics.summary: Christian advocates building with reference customers as the “holy grail” of discovery: create early users who love the solution enough to recommend it, making downstream sales/marketing easier and validating real demand.

topics.title: How many references signal product-market fit
topics.summary: They discuss practical thresholds (6–8 B2B, 15–25 B2C) and why recruiting willingness is itself a signal; Christian describes launching apps only after securing 25 five-star reviews from real target users.

topics.title: Defining “love”: reputation-on-the-line references
topics.summary: Christian defines product-market fit at the individual level as customers willing to put their reputation on the line (reviews/testimonials), using that commitment to surface honest feedback and refine positioning and pricing.

topics.title: One solution for many: avoiding custom one-offs
topics.summary: Christian emphasizes that reference-driven discovery only works if the same core solution satisfies the whole target set; if needs diverge, you narrow the market rather than customizing endlessly.

topics.title: Case study: high-volume hiring product built manually
topics.summary: Christian tells a detailed story starting with Starbucks’ urgent hiring crisis, then validating the broader problem via McDonald’s and others, iterating through manual recruiting, learning constraints (e.g., airports), and ultimately building software that drove $32M in sales in 90 days.
